In this section, technical standards document means a document, published in the prescribed manner by authority of the Minister, that reproduces in the official languages of Canada an enactment of a foreign government with any adaptations of form and reference that will facilitate the incorporation of the enactment under this section.

For greater certainty, regulations made under this Division may incorporate by reference a technical standards document as it reads on a prescribed day or as it is amended from time to time following the incorporation by reference, and may extend, qualify or exclude the application of any provision of the document so incorporated.

No person is required to comply with a provision of a technical standards document incorporated by the regulations until six months after the publication of the provision in the prescribed manner, if the person continues to comply with the provision for which that provision is substituted.
A technical standards document is not a regulation for the purposes of the Statutory Instruments Act.
Regulations that prescribe standards in relation to emissions may provide for a system of credits based on the following principles:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a company may establish that vehicles, engines or equipment conform to those standards by applying credits against emissions of the vehicles, engines or equipment in the prescribed manner and within prescribed limits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: credits may be obtained by a company in the prescribed manner

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by reference to emissions of the vehicles, engines or equipment that more than meet the requirements of those standards, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by the payment of an amount to the Receiver General determined at a prescribed rate in relation to emissions of the vehicle, engine or equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: credits obtained by reference to emissions may be transferred to or from a company in the prescribed manner.

Subsection.Text: Regulations referred to in subsection (1) may provide that any vehicle, engine or equipment is deemed to conform to a standard if the application of those regulations to all vehicles, engines or equipment of its class sold in Canada and the United States would result in that vehicle, engine or equipment so conforming.

Every company shall submit to the Minister, in the prescribed form and manner and at the prescribed time, a report setting out, with respect to a prescribed period, an account of any emission credits obtained or applied by the company and a description of each of the following vehicles, engines or pieces of equipment for which credits were obtained or applied:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vehicles, engines and equipment to which the company applied a national emissions mark during that period, other than those that were exported;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: vehicles, engines and equipment bearing a national emissions mark that were sold by the company in Canada during that period; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: vehicles, engines and equipment that were imported by the company during that period for the purpose of sale in Canada.

Subsection.Text: If credits applied under this section were obtained on the basis of emissions from vehicles, engines or equipment not referred to in paragraph (3)(a), (b) or (c), the report submitted in respect of the application of those credits shall include a description of those vehicles, engines or equipment.

If an enactment of a foreign government corresponds to the regulations made under this Division and that enactment is amended by that government or its operation is affected by a decision of a foreign court, the Minister may issue an interim order suspending or modifying the operation of the regulations to the extent that they are inconsistent with the enactment as amended or given effect.
An interim order has effect from the time it is made.
An interim order ceases to have effect 14 days after it is made unless it is approved by the Governor in Council within that period.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Contravention of regulation modified by an unpublished order
Subsection.Text: No person shall be convicted of an offence consisting of a contravention of a regulation to the extent that it is modified or suspended by an interim order that, at the time of the alleged contravention, had not been published in the Canada Gazette unless it is proved that, at the time of the alleged contravention, the person had been notified of the interim order.
Subject to subsection (3), an interim order ceases to have effect on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day it is repealed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day the regulation is amended or repealed to give effect to the order, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: one year after the order is made.

Section.Text: In a prosecution under this Act, evidence that any vehicle, engine or equipment bore a name or mark purporting to be the name or mark of a company engaged in the business of manufacturing, importing or selling vehicles, engines or equipment is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the vehicle, engine or equipment was manufactured, imported or sold, as the case may be, by the company.

In a prosecution under this Act, evidence that any vehicle, engine or equipment bearing a national emissions mark was manufactured by a company is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the national emissions mark was applied by the company.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), the Minister shall act under subsections (2) and (3) only if the Ministers have reason to believe that a substance released from a source in Canada into the air creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to contribute to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: air pollution in a country other than Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: air pollution that violates, or is likely to violate, an international agreement binding on Canada in relation to the prevention, control or correction of pollution.

Subsection.Text: If the source referred to in subsection (1) is not a federal source, the Minister shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consult with the government responsible for the area in which the source is situated to determine whether that government can prevent, control or correct the air pollution under its laws; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the government referred to in paragraph (a) can prevent, control or correct the air pollution, offer it an opportunity to do so.

Subsection.Text: If the source referred to in subsection (1) is a federal source or if the government referred to in paragraph (2)(a) cannot prevent, control or correct the air pollution under its laws or does not do so, the Minister shall take at least one of the following courses of action:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on approval by the Governor in Council, publish a notice under subsection 56(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: recommend regulations to the Governor in Council for the purpose of preventing, controlling or correcting the air pollution.

Subsection.Text: If the air pollution referred to in paragraph (1)(a) is in a country where Canada does not have substantially the same rights with respect to the prevention, control or correction of air pollution as that country has under this Division, the Minister shall decide whether to act under subsections (2) and (3) or to take no action at all.

When recommending regulations under paragraph (3)(b), the Minister shall take into account comments made under subsection 168(2), notices of objection filed under subsection 332(2) and any report of a board of review submitted under subsection 340(1).

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister, make regulations with respect to a substance released from a source in Canada into the air that creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to contribute to air pollution referred to in subsection 166(1) for the purpose of preventing, controlling or correcting the air pollution, including regulations respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity or concentration of the substance that may be released into the air;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which and conditions under which the substance may be released into the air, either alone or in combination with any other substance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance of books and records for the administration of any regulation made under this section;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance and the submission of the results to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for conducting sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall advise the government of any country that would be affected by or benefit from the regulation before it is published under subsection 332(1).

Within 60 days after the publication of a proposed regulation under subsection 332(1), any person, including a representative of the government of any country that would be affected by or benefit from it, may file with the Minister written comments on the proposed regulation.
At the end of the period of 60 days referred to in subsection (2), the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall advise each government referred to in paragraph 166(2)(a) of any notice of objection filed under subsection 332(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall publish in the Canada Gazette, and may publish in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, a report or a notice of the availability of a report that summarizes how any written comments filed under subsection (2) or a notice of objection filed under subsection 332(2) were dealt with.

Subsection.Text: Where there occurs or there is a likelihood of a release into the air of a substance in contravention of a regulation made under section 167, any person described in subsection (2) shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (4) and the regulations, notify an enforcement officer or any other person designated pursuant to the regulations and provide a written report on the matter to the enforcement officer or other person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take all reasonable measures consistent with the protection of the environment and public safety to prevent the release or, if it cannot be prevented, to remedy any dangerous condition or reduce or mitigate any danger to the environment or to human life or health that results from the release of the substance or may reasonably be expected to result if the substance is released; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make a reasonable effort to notify any member of the public who may be adversely affected by the release or likely release.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) applies to any person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owns or has charge of a substance immediately before its release or its likely release into the air; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes or contributes to the release or increases the likelihood of the release.

Subsection.Text: Where there occurs a release of a substance as described in subsection (1), any person, other than a person described in subsection (2), whose property is affected by the release shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances and subject to subsection (4), report the matter to an enforcement officer or to any person that is designated by regulation.

Where there are in force, by or under the laws of a province or an aboriginal government, provisions that the Governor in Council, by regulation, declares to be adequate for dealing with a release described in subsection (1), a report required by paragraph (1)(a) or subsection (3) shall be made to a person designated by those provisions.

Where a person fails to take any measures required under subsection (1), an enforcement officer may take those measures, cause them to be taken or direct any person referred to in subsection (2) to take them.
Any direction of an enforcement officer under subsection (5) that is inconsistent with a requirement imposed by or under any other Act of Parliament is void to the extent of the inconsistency.

Any enforcement officer or other person authorized or required to take any measures under subsection (1) or (5) may enter and have access to any place or property and may do any reasonable things that may be necessary in the circumstances.

Any person, other than a person described in subsection (2), who provides assistance or advice in taking the measures required by subsection (1) or who takes any measures authorized under subsection (5) is not personally liable either civilly or criminally in respect of any act or omission in the course of providing assistance or advice or taking any measures under those subsections unless it is established that the person acted in bad faith.

Section.MarginalNote: Recovery of reasonable costs and expenses by Her Majesty

Subsection.Text: Her Majesty in right of Canada may recover the costs and expenses of and incidental to taking any measures under subsection 169(5) from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 169(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 169(2)(b) to the extent of the person’s negligence in causing or contributing to the release.

Subsection.Text: The costs and expenses referred to in subsection (1) shall only be recovered to the extent that they can be established to have been reasonably incurred in the circumstances.
Subject to subsection (4), the persons referred to in subsection (1) are jointly and severally liable or solidarily liable for the costs and expenses referred to in that subsection.
A person referred to in paragraph 169(2)(b) shall not be held liable under subsection (3) to an extent greater than the extent of the person’s negligence in causing or contributing to the release.

A claim under this section may be sued for and recovered by Her Majesty in right of Canada with costs in proceedings brought or taken therefor in the name of Her Majesty in right of Canada in any court of competent jurisdiction.
This section does not limit or restrict any right of recourse or indemnity that a person may have against any other person.

Where events giving rise to a claim under this section occur, no proceedings in respect of the claim may be instituted after five years from the date on which the events occur or become evident to the Minister, whichever is later.

A document purporting to have been issued by the Minister certifying the day on which the events giving rise to a claim under this section came to the knowledge of the Minister shall be received in evidence and, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, the document shall be considered as proof of that fact without proof of the signature or of the official character of the person appearing to have signed the document and without further proof.

Section.Text: No person shall carry on a work, undertaking or activity that results in the release of a substance in contravention of a regulation made under section 167.

Subsection.Text: If a person carries on or proposes to carry on a work, undertaking or activity that results or may result in the release of a substance that creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to create, air pollution, the person shall, at the request of the Minister for the purposes of this Division and within the time that the Minister may specify, provide the Minister with plans, specifications, studies, procedures, schedules, analyses, samples or other information relating to the work, undertaking or activity and with analyses, samples, evaluations, studies, mitigation methodologies or other information relating to the substance.

Before making a request to a person under subsection (1), the Minister shall try to obtain, within a reasonable time, the samples or information from the government responsible for the area in which the person is situated.
The Minister may make an interim order that contains any provision that may be contained in a regulation under section 167 if the Minister believes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the substance or source referred to in subsection 166(1) is not adequately regulated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that immediate action is required to deal with a significant danger to the environment or to human life or health.

Subsection.Text: An interim order has effect from the time it is made.
An interim order ceases to have effect 14 days after it is made unless it is approved by the Governor in Council within that period.
The Governor in Council shall not approve an interim order unless the Minister has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 24 hours after making the order, offered to consult with all affected governments to determine whether they are prepared to take sufficient action to deal with the significant danger; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: consulted with other ministers of the Crown in right of Canada to determine whether any action can be taken under any other Act of Parliament to deal with the significant danger.

Subsection.Text: Where the Governor in Council approves an interim order, the Minister shall, within 90 days after the approval, take measures to comply with section 166 in order to address the significant danger that gave rise to the interim order.

No person shall be convicted of an offence consisting of a contravention of an interim order that, at the time of the alleged contravention, had not been published in the Canada Gazette unless it is proved that, at the time of the alleged contravention, the person had been notified of the interim order.
Subject to subsection (3), an interim order ceases to have effect on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day it is repealed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day a regulation is made in accordance with subsection (5), and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two years after the order is made.

Subsection.Text: No action is required to be taken under subsection (5) if the interim order is repealed.

Section.Text: The Minister shall include in the annual report required by section 342 a report on the administration of this Division.
In this Division, water pollution means a condition of water, arising wholly or partly from the presence in water of any substance, that directly or indirectly

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: endangers the health, safety or welfare of humans;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: interferes with the normal enjoyment of life or property;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: endangers the health of animal life;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: causes damage to plant life or to property; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: degrades or alters, or forms part of a process of degrading or alterating, an ecosystem to an extent that is detrimental to its use by humans, animals or plants.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), the Minister shall act under subsections (2) and (3) only if the Ministers have reason to believe that a substance released from a source in Canada into water creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to create,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: water pollution in a country other than Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: water pollution that violates, or is likely to violate, an international agreement binding on Canada in relation to the prevention, control or correction of pollution.

Subsection.Text: If the source referred to in subsection (1) is a not a federal source, the Minister shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consult with the government responsible for the area in which the source is situated to determine whether that government can prevent, control or correct the water pollution under its laws; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the government referred to in paragraph (a) can prevent, control or correct the water pollution, offer it an opportunity to do so.

Subsection.Text: If the source referred to in subsection (1) is a federal source, or if the government referred to in paragraph (2)(a) cannot prevent, control or correct the water pollution under its laws or does not do so, the Minister shall take at least one of the following courses of action:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on approval by the Governor in Council, publish a notice under subsection 56(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: recommend regulations to the Governor in Council for the purpose of preventing, controlling or correcting the water pollution.

Subsection.Text: If the water pollution referred to in paragraph (1)(a) is in a country where Canada does not have substantially the same rights with respect to the prevention, control or correction of water pollution as that country has under this Division, the Minister shall decide whether to act under subsections (2) and (3).

When recommending regulations under paragraph (3)(b), the Minister shall take into account comments made under subsection 178(2), notices of objection filed under subsection 332(2) and any report of a board of review submitted under subsection 340(1).

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister, make regulations with respect to a substance released from a source in Canada into water that creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to create, water pollution referred to in subsection 176(1) for the purpose of preventing, controlling or correcting the water pollution, including regulations respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity or concentration of the substance that may be released into water;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which and conditions under which the substance may be released into water, either alone or in combination with any other substance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance of books and records for the administration of any regulation made under this section;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance and the submission of the results to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for conducting sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall advise the government of any country that would be affected by or benefit from the regulation before it is published under subsection 332(1).

Within 60 days after the publication of a proposed regulation under subsection 332(1), any person, including a representative of the government of any country that would be affected by or benefit from it, may file with the Minister written comments on the proposed regulation.
At the end of the period of 60 days referred to in subsection (2), the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall advise each government referred to in paragraph 176(2)(a) of any notice of objection filed under subsection 332(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall publish in the Canada Gazette, and may publish in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, a report or a notice of the availability of a report that summarizes how any written comments filed under subsection (2) or a notice of objection filed under subsection 332(2) were dealt with.

Subsection.Text: Where there occurs or there is a likelihood of a release into waters of a substance in contravention of a regulation made under section 177, any person described in subsection (2) shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (4) and the regulations, notify an enforcement officer or any other person designated pursuant to the regulations and provide a written report on the matter to the enforcement officer or other person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take all reasonable measures consistent with the protection of the environment and public safety to prevent the release or, if it cannot be prevented, to remedy any dangerous condition or reduce or mitigate any danger to the environment or to human life or health that results from the release of the substance or may reasonably be expected to result if the substance is released; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make a reasonable effort to notify any member of the public who may be adversely affected by the release or likely release.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) applies to any person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owns or has charge of a substance immediately before its release or its likely release into water; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes or contributes to the release or increases the likelihood of the release.

Subsection.Text: Where there occurs a release of a substance as described in subsection (1), any person, other than a person described in subsection (2), whose property is affected by the release shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances and subject to subsection (4), report the matter to an enforcement officer or to any person that is designated by regulation.

Where there are in force, by or under the laws of a province or an aboriginal government, provisions that the Governor in Council, by regulation, declares to be adequate for dealing with a release described in subsection (1), a report required by paragraph (1)(a) or subsection (3) shall be made to a person designated by those provisions.

Where any person fails to take any measures required under subsection (1), an enforcement officer may take those measures, cause them to be taken or direct any person referred to in subsection (2) to take them.
Any direction of an enforcement officer under subsection (5) that is inconsistent with a requirement imposed by or under any other Act of Parliament is void to the extent of the inconsistency.

Any enforcement officer or other person authorized or required to take any measures under subsection (1) or (5) may enter and have access to any place or property and may do any reasonable things that may be necessary in the circumstances.

Any person, other than a person described in subsection (2), who provides assistance or advice in taking the measures required by subsection (1) or who takes any measures authorized under subsection (5) is not personally liable either civilly or criminally in respect of any act or omission in the course of providing assistance or advice or taking any measures under those subsections unless it is established that the person acted in bad faith.

Section.MarginalNote: Recovery of reasonable costs and expenses by Her Majesty

Subsection.Text: Her Majesty in right of Canada may recover the costs and expenses of and incidental to taking any measures under subsection 179(5) from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 179(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 179(2)(b) to the extent of the person’s negligence in causing or contributing to the release.

Subsection.Text: The costs and expenses referred to in subsection (1) shall only be recovered to the extent that they can be established to have been reasonably incurred in the circumstances.
Subject to subsection (4), the persons referred to in subsection (1) are jointly and severally liable or solidarily liable for the costs and expenses referred to in that subsection.
A person referred to in paragraph 179(2)(b) shall not be held liable under subsection (3) to an extent greater than the extent of the person’s negligence in causing or contributing to the release.

A claim under this section may be sued for and recovered by Her Majesty in right of Canada with costs in proceedings brought or taken therefor in the name of Her Majesty in right of Canada in any court of competent jurisdiction.
This section does not limit or restrict any right of recourse or indemnity that a person may have against any other person.

Where events giving rise to a claim under this section occur, no proceedings in respect of the claim may be instituted after five years from the date on which the events occur or become evident to the Minister, whichever is later.

A document purporting to have been issued by the Minister certifying the day on which the events giving rise to a claim under this section came to the knowledge of the Minister shall be received in evidence and, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, the document shall be considered as proof of that fact without proof of the signature or of the official character of the person appearing to have signed the document and without further proof.

Section.Text: No person shall carry on a work, undertaking or activity that results in the release of a substance in contravention of a regulation made under section 177.

Subsection.Text: If a person carries on or proposes to carry on a work, undertaking or activity that results or may result in the release of a substance that creates, or may reasonably be anticipated to create, water pollution, the person shall, at the request of the Minister for the purposes of this Division and within the time that the Minister may specify, provide the Minister with plans, specifications, studies, procedures, schedules, analyses, samples or other information relating to the work, undertaking or activity and with analyses, samples, evaluations, studies, mitigation methodologies or other information relating to the substance.

Before making a request to a person under subsection (1), the Minister shall try to obtain, within a reasonable time, the samples or information from the government responsible for the area in which the person is situated.
The Minister may make an interim order that contains any provision that may be contained in a regulation under section 177 if the Minister believes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the substance or source referred to in subsection 176(1) is not adequately regulated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that immediate action is required to deal with a significant danger to the environment or to human life or health.

Subsection.Text: An interim order has effect from the time it is made.
An interim order ceases to have effect 14 days after it is made unless it is approved by the Governor in Council within that period.
The Governor in Council shall not approve an interim order unless the Minister has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 24 hours after making the order, offered to consult with all affected governments to determine whether they are prepared to take sufficient action to deal with the significant danger; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: consulted with other ministers of the Crown in right of Canada to determine whether any action can be taken under any other Act of Parliament to deal with the significant danger.

Subsection.Text: Where the Governor in Council approves an interim order, the Minister shall, within 90 days after the approval, take measures to comply with section 176 in order to address the significant danger that gave rise to the interim order.

No person shall be convicted of an offence consisting of a contravention of an interim order that, at the time of the alleged contravention, had not been published in the Canada Gazette unless it is proved that, at the time of the alleged contravention, the person had been notified of the interim order.
Subject to subsection (3), an interim order ceases to have effect on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day it is repealed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day a regulation is made in accordance with subsection (5), and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two years after the order is made.

Subsection.Text: No action is required to be taken under subsection (5) if the interim order is repealed.

Section.Text: The Minister shall include in the annual report required by section 342 a report on the administration of this Division.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 8
Heading.TitleText: Control of Movement of Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Recyclable Material and of Prescribed Non-hazardous Waste for Final Disposal

Subsection.Text: No person shall import, export or convey in transit a hazardous waste or hazardous recyclable material, or prescribed non-hazardous waste for final disposal, except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: after notifying the Minister and paying the prescribed fee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after receiving from the Minister whichever one of the following permits is applicable:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an import permit or export permit that, except in the case of a permit issued under subsection (4), states that the authorities of the country of destination and, if applicable, of the country of transit have authorized the movement, and that the authorities of the jurisdiction of destination have authorized the final disposal or recycling of the waste or material, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a transit permit that states that the Minister has authorized the movement; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the prescribed conditions.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister is of the opinion that the waste or material will not be managed in a manner that will protect the environment and human health against the adverse effects that may result from that waste or material, the Minister may refuse, in accordance with the criteria set out in the regulations, to issue a permit even if the relevant authorities have given their authorization.
Before refusing under subsection (2) to issue a permit to import, the Minister shall consult with the government of the jurisdiction of destination.

Where the Minister is of the opinion that the waste or material will be managed in a manner that will protect the environment and human health against the adverse effects that may result from that waste or material, the Minister may issue a permit if the relevant authorities inform the Minister that they lack the legal authority to authorize the movement, final disposal or recycling but are not opposed to it.

For the purpose of implementing international agreements respecting the environment, the Minister may, with the approval of the Governor in Council and taking into account Canada’s international obligations, prohibit, completely or partially and under any conditions that may be prescribed, the import, export or transit of waste or material referred to in subsection 185(1).
No person shall abandon any waste or material referred to in subsection 185(1) in the course of import, export or transit.

Section.Text: After the Minister receives a notification of the proposed import, export or transit of a waste or material referred to in paragraph 185(1)(a), the Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette, or in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, the name or specifications of the waste or material and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a proposed import, the name of the jurisdiction of origin and the name of the importer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a proposed export, the name of the jurisdiction of destination and the name of the exporter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a proposed transit, the names of the jurisdictions of origin and of destination and the name of the conveyor.

Section.MarginalNote: Reduction of export for final disposal

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of reducing or phasing out the export of hazardous waste or prescribed non-hazardous waste for final disposal, the Minister may require an exporter, or a class of exporters, of hazardous waste to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister, at the same time as the notification referred to in paragraph 185(1)(a) and at any other prescribed time, a plan in accordance with the regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: implement that plan.

Subsection.Text: Every person who is required to implement a plan under paragraph (1)(b) shall file with the Minister, within 30 days after the completion of each stage of the plan, a written declaration that the implementation has been completed.
The Minister may refuse to issue a permit to an exporter who does not comply with subsection (1) or (2).

No person shall undertake movement within Canada of hazardous waste or hazardous recyclable material otherwise than in accordance with this Division and the regulations and unless the person pays the prescribed fee.

The Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette, or in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, information derived from documents received under regulations made for the purpose of this section.

Section.MarginalNote: Permits based on equivalent environmental safety level

Subsection.Text: The Minister may issue a permit authorizing, subject to conditions fixed by the Minister, any activity to be conducted in a manner that does not comply with this Division if the Minister is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which the activity will be conducted provides a level of environmental safety at least equivalent to that provided by compliance with this Division; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the importation, exportation or transit of a waste or material referred to in subsection 185(1), the activity is consistent with international environmental agreements binding on Canada.

Subsection.Text: The permit may authorize the activity in terms of the persons who may conduct the activity and in terms of the waste and material that it may involve.
The Minister may revoke the permit if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister is of the opinion that paragraph (1)(a) or (b) no longer applies;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the regulations have been amended and address the activity authorized by the permit; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the permit holder does not comply with the conditions of the permit.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette, or in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, a copy of each permit issued under this section.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister, make regulations generally for carrying out the purposes and provisions of this Division, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: defining, for the purposes of this Division and Part 10, words and expressions used in this Division, and providing criteria, testing protocols and standards in relation to those definitions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the notification referred to in paragraph 185(1)(a) and the procedure for applying for a permit under this Division;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establishing criteria for the purpose of subsection 185(2) that take into account obligations arising from international agreements to which Canada is a party;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for establishing a classification system for waste and material;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting information and documents to be provided to the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: respecting conditions governing the import, export, transit and movement within Canada of waste and material;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: respecting plans referred to in subsection 188(1), taking into account

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the benefit of using the nearest appropriate disposal facility, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: changes in the quantity of goods the production of which generates hazardous waste to be disposed of by an exporter or class of exporters; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing anything that by this Division is to be prescribed.

Section.Text: The Minister may establish forms for the purposes of this Division.
The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: environmental emergency means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an uncontrolled, unplanned or accidental release, or release in contravention of regulations or interim orders made under this Part, of a substance into the environment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasonable likelihood of such a release into the environment.

Definition.Text: substance means, except in sections 199 and 200.1, a substance on a list of substances established under regulations or interim orders made under this Part.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Part, any power, duty or function conferred or imposed under this Part may only be exercised or performed in relation to those aspects of an environmental emergency that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have or may have an immediate or long-term harmful effect on the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: constitute or may constitute a danger to the environment on which human life depends; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: constitute or may constitute a danger in Canada to human life or health.

Section.Text: Despite subsection 36(3) of the Fisheries Act, subsection 123(1) and regulations made under paragraphs 93(1)(a), (b), (c) and (d) and 209(2)(a), (b), (c) and (d), the Minister may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: examine and conduct research, including tests, respecting the causes, circumstances and effects of and remedial measures for an environmental emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct and publicize demonstration projects.

Section.Text: The Minister may issue guidelines and codes of practice respecting the prevention of, preparedness for and response to an environmental emergency and for restoring any part of the environment damaged by or during an emergency.

Subsection.Text: In carrying out the responsibilities conferred by section 196, the Minister shall offer to consult with the government of a province and the members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments and may consult with a government department or agency, aboriginal people, representatives of industry and labour and municipal authorities or with persons interested in the quality of the environment or environmental emergencies.

At any time after the 60th day following the day on which the Minister offers to consult in accordance with subsection (1), the Minister may act under section 196 if the offer to consult is not accepted by the government of a province or members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments.

Section.MarginalNote: Publication of guidelines and codes of practice
Section.Text: The Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette, or in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, guidelines and codes of practice issued under section 196 or a notice stating where copies of those documents may be obtained.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may at any time publish in the Canada Gazette, and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, a notice requiring any person or class of persons described in the notice to prepare and implement an environmental emergency plan respecting the prevention of, preparedness for, response to or recovery from an environmental emergency in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a substance or group of substances on the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a substance or group of substances in relation to which there has been published in the Canada Gazette

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement of the Ministers under paragraph 77(6)(b) indicating that the measure that they propose to take, as confirmed or amended, is a recommendation that the substance be added to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a copy of an order proposed to be made under subsection 90(1).

Subsection.Text: The notice shall specify

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the substance or group of substances in relation to which the plan is to be prepared;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the period within which the plan is to be prepared;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the period within which the plan is to be implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that the Minister considers necessary.

Subsection.Text: Where the Minister is of the opinion that further time is necessary to prepare or implement the plan, the Minister may extend the period for a person who submits a written request before the expiry of the period referred to in the notice or of any extended period.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Plan prepared or implemented for another purpose
Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (5), where a person who is required to prepare or implement an environmental emergency plan under a notice published under this section has prepared or implemented a plan in respect of environmental emergencies on a voluntary basis or for another government or under another Act of Parliament that meets all or some of the requirements of the notice, the person may use that plan for the purposes of meeting the requirements of this Part and, in that case, the plan shall be considered to be an environmental emergency plan that has been prepared or implemented under this Part.
Where a person uses a plan under subsection (4) that does not meet all of the requirements of the notice, the person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: amend the plan so that it meets all of those requirements; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prepare an additional environmental emergency plan that meets the remainder of those requirements.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Application of provisions re declarations and keeping plans
Subsection.Text: Sections 58 and 59 apply to environmental emergency plans, with any modifications that the circumstances require, as if any reference to a pollution prevention plan were read as a reference to an environmental emergency plan.

The Minister may publish in the Canada Gazette, and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate, a notice requiring any person or class of persons described in the notice who are required to prepare or implement an environmental emergency plan under subsection (1) or section 291 or under an agreement in respect of environmental protection alternative measures to submit, within the period specified by the Minister, the plan or any part of the plan.
The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister and after the Committee is given an opportunity to provide its advice to the Minister under section 6, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establishing a list of substances that, if they enter the environment as a result of an environmental emergency,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: have or may have an immediate or long-term harmful effect on the environment or its biological diversity,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: constitute or may constitute a danger to the environment on which human life depends, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: constitute or may constitute a danger in Canada to human life or health;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing, in respect of a substance on the list established under paragraph (a), a minimum quantity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the identification of the places in Canada where a substance referred to in paragraph (a), in any quantity or in the quantity prescribed for that substance under paragraph (b), is located and requiring notification to the Minister of those places;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the prevention of, preparedness for, response to and recovery from an environmental emergency in respect of a substance;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the notification and reporting of an environmental emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the notification and reporting of the measures taken

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to prevent the environmental emergency, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to repair, reduce or mitigate any negative effects on the environment or human life or health that result from the environmental emergency or that may reasonably be expected to result from it;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the implementation of international agreements entered into by Canada in relation to environmental emergencies; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: respecting any other matter necessary for the purposes of this Part.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Environmental emergencies regulated under other Acts of Parliament
Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council shall not make a regulation under subsection (1) in respect of a matter if, by order, the Governor in Council states that it is of the opinion that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the matter is regulated by or under any other Act of Parliament that contains provisions that are similar in effect to sections 194 to 205; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that Act or any regulation made under that Act provides sufficient protection to human health and the environment or its biological diversity.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may make an interim order, in respect of a substance, that contains any provision that may be contained in a regulation made under this Part, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the substance

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is not on the list established under regulations made under this Part and the Ministers believe that, if it enters the environment as a result of an environmental emergency,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: it would have or may have an immediate or long-term harmful effect on the environment or its biological diversity,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: it would constitute or may constitute a danger to the environment on which human life depends, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: it would constitute or may constitute a danger in Canada to human life or health, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is on that list and the Ministers believe that it is not adequately regulated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Ministers believe that immediate action is required to deal with a significant danger to the environment or to human life or health.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), an interim order has effect

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from the time it is made; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as if it were a regulation made under this Part.

Subsection.Text: An interim order ceases to have effect unless it is approved by the Governor in Council within 14 days after it is made.
The Governor in Council shall not approve an interim order unless the Minister has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 24 hours after making the order, offered to consult with all affected governments to determine whether they are prepared to take sufficient action to deal with the significant danger; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: consulted with other ministers of the Crown in right of Canada to determine whether any action can be taken under any other Act of Parliament to deal with the significant danger.

Subsection.Text: If the Governor in Council approves an interim order, the Minister shall, within 90 days after the approval, publish in the Canada Gazette a statement indicating whether the Minister intends to recommend to the Governor in Council

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that a regulation having the same effect as the order be made under this Part; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the order was made in respect of a substance that was not on the list established under regulations made under this Part, that the substance be added to that list.

Subsection.Text: No person shall be convicted of an offence consisting of a contravention of an interim order that, at the time of the alleged contravention, had not been published in the Canada Gazette unless it is proved that, at the time of the alleged contravention, the person had been notified of the interim order or reasonable steps had been taken to bring the purport of the interim order to the notice of those persons likely to be affected by it.
Subject to subsection (3), an interim order ceases to have effect on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day it is repealed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day a regulation referred to in subsection (5) is made, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two years after the order is made.

Subsection.Text: A copy of each interim order must be tabled in each House of Parliament within 15 days after it is made.
In order to comply with subsection (8), the interim order may be sent to the Clerk of the House if the House is not sitting.

Subject to any regulations made under subsection 200(1) or any interim orders made under section 200.1, if there occurs an environmental emergency in respect of a substance on a list established under the regulations or interim orders, any person described in subsection (2) shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify an enforcement officer or any other person designated by regulation or interim order and provide a written report on the environmental emergency to the enforcement officer or other person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take all reasonable emergency measures consistent with the protection of the environment and public safety

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to prevent the environmental emergency, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to repair, reduce or mitigate any negative effects on the environment or human life or health that result from the environmental emergency or that may reasonably be expected to result from it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make a reasonable effort to notify any member of the public who may be adversely affected by the environmental emergency.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) applies to any person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owns or has the charge, management or control of a substance immediately before the environmental emergency; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes or contributes to the environmental emergency.

Subsection.Text: A person, other than a person described in subsection (2), shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances, report an environmental emergency to an enforcement officer or to a person designated by regulation or interim order if their property is affected by the environmental emergency.

Where any person fails to take any measures required under subsection (1), an enforcement officer may take those measures, cause them to be taken or direct any person referred to in subsection (2) to take them.
Any direction of an enforcement officer under subsection (4) that is inconsistent with a requirement imposed by or under any other Act of Parliament is void to the extent of the inconsistency.

Any enforcement officer or other person authorized or required to take any measures under subsection (1) or (4) may enter and have access to any place or property and may do anything reasonable that may be necessary in the circumstances.

Any person, other than a person described in subsection (2), who provides assistance or advice in taking the measures required by subsection (1) or who takes any measures authorized under subsection (4) is not personally liable either civilly or criminally in respect of any act or omission in the course of providing assistance or advice or taking any measures under those subsections unless it is established that the person acted in bad faith.

If a person knows about an environmental emergency but the person is not required to report the matter under this Act, the person may report any information about the environmental emergency to an enforcement officer or to a person designated by regulation or interim order.
The person making the report may request that their identity and any information that could reasonably reveal their identity not be released.

No person shall disclose, or have disclosed, the identity of the person making the request or any information that could reasonably be expected to reveal their identity unless the person making the request authorizes the disclosure in writing.
Despite any other Act of Parliament, no employer shall dismiss, suspend, demote, discipline, harass or otherwise disadvantage an employee, or deny an employee a benefit of employment, by reason that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the employee has made a report under subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee, acting in good faith and on the basis of reasonable belief, has refused or stated an intention of refusing to do anything that is an offence under this Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employee, acting in good faith and on the basis of reasonable belief, has done or stated an intention of doing anything that is required to be done by or under this Act.

Subsection.Text: Her Majesty in right of Canada may recover the costs and expenses of and incidental to taking any measures under subsection 201(4) from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 201(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 201(2)(b) to the extent of their negligence or wilful conduct in causing or contributing to the environmental emergency.

Subsection.Text: The costs and expenses referred to in subsection (1) shall only be recovered to the extent that they can be established to have been reasonably incurred in the circumstances.
Subject to subsection (4), the persons referred to in subsection (1) are jointly and severally liable or solidarily liable for the costs and expenses referred to in that subsection.

A person referred to in paragraph 201(2)(b) shall not be held liable under subsection (3) to an extent greater than the extent of their negligence or wilful conduct in causing or contributing to the environmental emergency.

A claim under this section may be sued for and recovered by Her Majesty in right of Canada with costs in proceedings brought or taken therefor in the name of Her Majesty in right of Canada in any court of competent jurisdiction.
This section does not limit or restrict any right of recourse or indemnity that a person may have against any other person.

Where events giving rise to a claim under this section occur, no proceedings in respect of the claim may be instituted after five years from the date on which the events occur or become evident to the Minister, whichever is later.

A document purporting to have been issued by the Minister certifying the day on which the events giving rise to a claim under this section came to the knowledge of the Minister shall be received in evidence and, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, the document shall be considered as proof of that fact without proof of the signature or of the official character of the person appearing to have signed the document and without further proof.

The Minister may establish, in cooperation with the governments of the provinces and aboriginal governments and government departments or agencies, a national system for the notification and reporting of environmental emergencies.
Subject to section 314, any person may have access to and a copy of any information contained in the national system established under subsection (1).
Subject to this Part, the person who owns or has the charge, management or control of a substance immediately before an environmental emergency is liable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for restoring any part of the environment damaged by or during the emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for costs and expenses incurred by a public department within the meaning of the Criminal Code or other public authority in Canada in respect of measures taken to prevent, repair, remedy or minimize the damage to the environment resulting from the emergency, including measures taken in anticipation of the environmental emergency, to the extent that the measures taken and the costs and expenses are reasonable, and for any loss or damage caused by such measures; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for costs and expenses incurred by the Minister in respect of measures taken to prevent, repair, remedy or minimize the environmental emergency to the extent that the measures taken and the costs and expenses are reasonable, and for any loss or damage caused by such measures.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of public authority in Canada
Subsection.Text: In subsection (1), public authority in Canada means Her Majesty in right of a province, an aboriginal government or any other body designated by the Governor in Council for the purposes of that subsection as a public authority in Canada.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Strict liability subject to certain defences
Subsection.Text: The person’s liability under subsection (1) does not depend on proof of fault or negligence, but the owner is not liable under that subsection if the owner establishes that the environmental emergency

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: resulted from an act of war, hostilities or insurrection or from a natural phenomenon of an exceptional, inevitable and irresistible character;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was wholly caused by an act or omission of a third party with intent to cause damage; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: was wholly caused by the negligence or other wrongful act of government, public department or public authority.

Subsection.Text: Where the person who is liable under subsection (1) establishes that the environmental emergency resulted wholly or partially from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an act or omission done by the person who suffered the damage with intent to cause damage, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the negligence or wilful conduct of that person,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the liability of the person referred to in subsection (1) to that other person is reduced or nullified in proportion to the degree to which the environmental emergency resulted from the factors mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Person’s rights against third parties preserved
Subsection.Text: Nothing in this Part shall be construed as limiting or restricting any right of recourse that the person who is liable under subsection (1) may have against any other person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Person’s own claim for costs and expenses
Subsection.Text: Costs and expenses incurred by the person referred to in subsection (1) in respect of measures voluntarily taken to prevent, repair, remedy or minimize damage from the environmental emergency, including measures taken in anticipation of an environmental emergency, to the extent that the measures taken and the costs and expenses are reasonable, rank equally with other claims against any security given by that person in respect of that person’s liability under this section.

Heading.Label: PART 9
Heading.TitleText: Government Operations and Federal and Aboriginal Land

Section.Text: In this Part, regulations means regulations made under this Part.

Subsection.Text: This Part applies to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: departments, boards and agencies of the Government of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: federal works and undertakings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aboriginal land, federal land, persons on that land and other persons in so far as their activities involve that land; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Crown corporations, as defined in subsection 83(1) of the Financial Administration Act.

Subsection.Text: This Part does not apply to public real property under the administration and control of the Commissioner of Yukon pursuant to the Yukon Act.
This Part does not restrict any of the following powers in so far as they may be exercised in relation to air and all layers of the atmosphere above federal land or aboriginal land:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: powers under the Aeronautics Act or a provision of any other Act of Parliament relating to aeronautics or air transportation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: powers under the National Defence Act or a provision of any other Act of Parliament relating to national defence and security.

Heading.TitleText: Objectives, Guidelines and Codes of Practice

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall establish objectives, guidelines and codes of practice for the purpose of carrying out the Minister’s duties and functions under this Part related to the quality of the environment.
In establishing an objective, a guideline or a code of practice under subsection (1), the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall offer to consult with the government of a territory if the objective, guideline or code of practice applies to that territory, and with the members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments if it applies to aboriginal land over which an aboriginal government has jurisdiction; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may consult with a department, board or agency of the Government of Canada, or a Crown corporation as defined in subsection 83(1) of the Financial Administration Act.

Subsection.Text: At any time after the 60th day following the day on which the Minister offers to consult in accordance with paragraph (2)(a), the Minister may act under subsection (1) if the offer to consult is not accepted by the government of a territory or members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments.

Section.MarginalNote: Regulations for the protection of the environment

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister, make regulations for the protection of the environment, including, but not limited to, regulations respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the establishment of environmental management systems;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pollution prevention and pollution prevention plans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: environmental emergencies, releases of substances and likely releases, including their prevention, preparedness for them, reporting them, both as soon as possible in the circumstances and in detail at a later stage, and the measures to be taken to respond to them and to correct damage to the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the designation of persons for the purposes of paragraph 212(1)(a) and subsections 212(3) and 213(1) and prescribing the form of the report to be made under those provisions and the information to be contained in it;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances in which a report is not required under paragraph 212(1)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any substance; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter necessary to carry out the purposes of this Part.

Subsection.Text: Regulations with respect to any substance may provide for, or impose requirements respecting,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity or concentration of any substance that may be released into the environment either alone or in combination with any other substance from any source or type of source;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the places or areas where the substance may be released;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the commercial, manufacturing, processing or other activity in the course of which the substance may be released;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which and the conditions under which the substance may be released into the environment, either alone or in combination with any other substance;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the substance that may be manufactured, processed, used, offered for sale or sold in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the purposes for which the substance or a product containing it may be imported, manufactured, processed, used, offered for sale or sold;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which and the conditions under which the substance or a product containing it may be imported, manufactured, processed or used;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the quantities or concentrations in which the substance may be used;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the quantities or concentrations of the substance that may be imported;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the countries from or to which the substance may be imported or exported;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions under which, the manner in which and the purposes for which the substance may be imported or exported;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the total, partial or conditional prohibition of the manufacture, use, processing, sale, offering for sale, import or export of the substance or a product containing the substance and the total, partial or conditional prohibition of the import or export of a product that is intended to contain the substance;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity or concentration of the substance that may be contained in any product manufactured, imported, exported, sold or offered for sale in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which, the conditions under which and the purposes for which the substance or a product containing it may be advertised or offered for sale;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which and the conditions under which the substance or a product containing it may be stored, displayed, handled, transported or offered for transport;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: the packaging and labelling of the substance or a product containing it;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the manner, conditions, places and method of disposal or recycling of the substance or a product containing it, including standards for the construction, maintenance and inspection of disposal or recycling sites;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the submission to the Minister, on request or at any times that are prescribed, of information relating to the substance;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance of books and records for the administration of any regulation made under this section;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance and the submission of the results to the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the submission of samples of the substance to the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for conducting sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring of the substance;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances or conditions under which the Minister may, for the proper administration of this Act, modify

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any requirement for sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices for conducting any required sampling, analyses, tests, measurements or monitoring; and

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: the decommissioning and decontamination of storage, handling, transportation, disposal and recycling sites for the substance.

Subsection.Text: Before recommending to the Governor in Council a regulation under this section, the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall offer to consult with the government of a territory if the regulation applies to that territory, and with the members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments if it applies to aboriginal land over which an aboriginal government has jurisdiction; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may consult with a department, board or agency of the Government of Canada, or a Crown corporation as defined in subsection 83(1) of the Financial Administration Act.

Subsection.Text: At any time after the 60th day following the day on which the Minister offers to consult in accordance with paragraph (3)(a), the Minister may recommend a regulation to the Governor in Council under this section if the offer to consult is not accepted by the government of a territory or members of the Committee who are representatives of aboriginal governments.

Section.Text: Where the Governor in Council is of the opinion that provisions of any other Part of this Act or any other Act of Parliament, or regulations made under them,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are in force in respect of an aspect of the protection of the environment,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: apply to a federal work or undertaking, federal land or aboriginal land, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide sufficient protection to the environment and human health,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Governor in Council may make an order stating that opinion and, if such an order is made, regulations made under this Part relating to the same aspect do not apply to the federal work or undertaking, the federal land or the aboriginal land.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of making regulations, the Minister may require information from any person who carries on, or proposes to carry on, a federal work or undertaking or an activity on federal land or aboriginal land.
The required information shall be information that will enable the Minister to determine any environmental effects that the work, undertaking or activity may have, and it may include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: plans, specifications, studies, procedures, schedules, analyses, samples or other information relating to the work, undertaking or activity; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: analyses, samples, evaluations, studies or other information relating to the environment that is or is likely to be affected by the work, undertaking or activity.

Subsection.Text: If a substance is released into the environment in contravention of a regulation, or if there is a likelihood of such a release, a person described in subsection (2) shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to the regulations, notify an enforcement officer or any other person designated pursuant to the regulations and provide a written report on the matter to the enforcement officer or other person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take all reasonable measures consistent with the protection of the environment and public safety to prevent or eliminate any dangerous condition or minimize any danger to the environment or to human life or health that results from the release or may reasonably be expected to result if the substance is released; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make a reasonable effort to notify any members of the public who may be adversely affected by the release or likely release.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) applies to any person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owns or has the charge, management or control of the substance immediately before its release or its likely release into the environment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: causes or contributes to the release or increases the likelihood of the release.

Subsection.Text: A person, other than a person described in subsection (2), shall, as soon as possible in the circumstances, report a release of a substance to an enforcement officer or to a person designated by the regulations if their property is affected by the release and they know that the substance has been released in contravention of a regulation.
Where measures required by subsection (1) are not taken, an enforcement officer may take them, have them taken or direct a person described in subsection (2) to take them.
If the direction to the person described in subsection (2) is inconsistent with a requirement imposed by or under any other Act of Parliament, it is void to the extent of the inconsistency.

An enforcement officer or other person authorized or required to take measures under subsection (1) or (4) may, for the purpose of taking those measures, enter and have access to any place or property and may do anything reasonable that may be necessary in the circumstances.

A person who provides assistance or advice in taking the measures required by subsection (1), or who takes any measures authorized under subsection (4), is not personally liable either civilly or criminally for any act or omission in the course of providing assistance or advice or taking any measures under those subsections, unless it is established that the person acted in bad faith.

If a person knows about a release or likely release of a substance into the environment in contravention of a regulation but the person is not required to report the matter under this Act, the person may report any information about the release or likely release to an enforcement officer or to a person designated by the regulations.
The person making the report may request that their identity and any information that could reasonably reveal their identity not be released.

No person shall disclose, or have disclosed, the identity of the person making the request or any information that could reasonably be expected to reveal their identity unless the person making the request authorizes the disclosure in writing.
Despite any other Act of Parliament, no employer shall dismiss, suspend, demote, discipline, harass or otherwise disadvantage an employee, or deny an employee a benefit of employment, by reason that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the employee has made a report under subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee, acting in good faith and on the basis of reasonable belief, has refused or stated an intention of refusing to do anything that is an offence under this Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the employee, acting in good faith and on the basis of reasonable belief, has done or stated an intention of doing anything that is required to be done by or under this Act.

Subsection.Text: The costs and expenses related to taking any measures under subsection 212(4) may be recovered by Her Majesty in right of Canada from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 212(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person referred to in paragraph 212(2)(b) to the extent of their negligence or wilful conduct in causing or contributing to the release.

Subsection.Text: The costs and expenses may only be recovered to the extent that they have been reasonably incurred in the circumstances.
